Keyword

　Terms have the highest precedence in expression evaluation. These are the usual immediates, the identifier ( → token ) , as well as:

true and false

　true and false (true and false) are treated as integer values with the values 1 and 0, respectively.

　Avoid comparing true and false with other expressions. For example, do not do something like if (true != GetBoolean()) , but write something like if (!GetBoolen()). In the logical expression, "0 is false" and "other than 0 is true", not "1 is true", and TJS2 has no logical type (Boolean), so this is because the conversion of the typical numerical value ← → logical type is not performed.

void

　void indicates "none." Used in a variety of ways to represent "nothing." Not the same as null.
　The variable you just declared (the one with no assignment) is this value.
　If treated as a character string, it will be an empty string (''). If treated as a number, it will be 0.

　We recommend that you use the === or !== (identify) operator to compare void.

null

　null indicates that the object is "not indicating any object". Not the same as void.
　Attempting to access a null object will result in an error.
　Changing the context to null using the incontextof operator causes the function to be executed on the context where it was called.

例:
    var objmethod = obj.method;
    objmethod(); // run in the context of obj
    objmethod = objmethod incontextof null; // Change context to null
    objmethod(); // run on this (ie the context at the call location)

Infinity

　Infinity represents infinity. -Infinity represents negative infinity.

NaN

　NaN stands for Not a Number. Not-a-number is a number that can be obtained if the result of a calculation is invalid.

super

　super represents the class's superclass in the class's methods / properties. Attempting to reference a non-class method / property or within a class that has multiple inheritance will result in an error.

global

　global represents a global object. You can access variables, classes, functions that are not methods of the class, and so on, declared outside all blocks.


例:
    var v;
    function test(v)
    {
        global.v=v;  // Set v of argument to v of global
    }

this

　this represents the object itself of a class, usually within a method or property of the class.
　The "context" specified explicitly or implicitly at the time of the call is specified as this.

Function in expression

　You can write a function in an expression using function. See function.

Array in expression

　You can use [ ] to describe an object of class Array on the fly in an expression. See Array class.

Dictionary array in expression

　You can use %[] to describe an object of the Dictionary class on the fly in an expression. See Dictionary class.
